title: Invest 97L forecast : Tropical disturbance tracking towards Gulf of Mexico , near Florida
message:
The National Hurricane Center (NHC) said a tropical disturbance over Hispaniola, known as Invest 97L, is highly likely to develop further over the next seven days and possibly become a tropical depression as early as this weekend.
As it moves toward the Gulf of Mexico, it's expected to enter an environment more favorable for further development.
The NHC said it could become a tropical depression this weekend or early next week over the Gulf of Mexico, not far from Florida.
"Interests across the Greater Antilles, the Bahamas, and Florida should continue to monitor the progress of this system," the NHC said.
The tropical wave is getting more organized now and is starting to produce some big thunderstorms, as seen from satellite.
location: The main event is a tropical disturbance over Hispaniola.

title: High chance of a tropical system targeting Florida this weekend
message:
Forecast Centre The Weather Network A tropical disturbance has a high chance of developing into a storm by this weekend as it approaches FloridaFlorida is on alert as a tropical disturbance gathering steam over the northern Caribbean takes aim at the state this weekend.
Forecasters give the disturbance a 70 percent (high) chance of developing into a tropical depression or a tropical storm over the next couple of days.
Vacationers are advised to keep a close watch on forecasts over the coming days as this system draws closer to the Sunshine State.
Environmental conditions around the disturbance will gradually become favourable for tropical development as it moves west-northwest toward Florida this weekend.

title: At least 30 dead after Typhoon Gaemi cut off towns in China Hunan province - Boston News , Weather , Sports
message:
Hong Kong (CNN) — Heavy rains and floods from Typhoon Gaemi caused at least 30 deaths and left 35 people missing across eight towns in the southern Chinese province of Hunan, state-run news agency Xinhua reported on Thursday, citing local authorities.
On Thursday, rescue teams reached eight towns that had been cut off from the outside world since last Sunday, due to destroyed infrastructure and power grids.
Typhoon Gaemi initially made landfall in China on the evening of Thursday July 25, with winds approaching 110 kph (70 mph).
The storm previously caused torrential flooding in Taiwan, with rainfall in five townships totaling over 1,285mm (50 inches).
Typhoon Gaemi was deflected off its forecasted track by Taiwan’s mountainous terrain and spent more than six hours offshore, making a loop near the Hualien coastline instead of making landfall on the evening of Wednesday, July 24.
event_breakdown: Typhoon Gaemi caused at least 30 deaths and left 35 people missing across eight towns in the southern Chinese province of Hunan, state-run news agency Xinhua reported on Thursday, citing local authorities. Heavy rains and floods caused significant damage to China's infrastructure last week, including in Hunan province and the city of Xiamen.

title: The Jasper fire highlights the risks climate change poses to Canada world heritage sites
message:
The catastrophic Jasper fire highlights the vulnerability of Canada’s UNESCO World Heritage sites to the dual threat of climate change and extreme weather events, particularly wildfires.
Becoming recognizedBecoming a UNESCO world heritage site is a recognition only a few places around the world have achieved.
According to the World Heritage Convention — the world heritage site system’s founding document — world heritage sites possess:“priceless and irreplaceable assets, not only of each nation, but of humanity as a whole.
Many of Canada’s world heritage sites are at an increasing risk of wildfire in a warming world.
It is essential that protecting Canada’s world heritage sites from fire be a key component of any national wildfire strategy.

title: Govt must provide additional disaster management funds to states without discrimination : Kharge
message:
Amid natural calamities in various parts of the country, Congress president Mallikarjun Kharge on Friday demanded that the Modi government should immediately provide additional disaster management funds to states without any discrimination.
He made the remarks while condoling the loss of lives due to cloudburst and heavy rainfall in Uttarakhand.
"The country is grappling with climate change, where floods, heavy rainfall, cloudburst and drought-like emergent situations have occurred in many states.
"We will also have to improve our disaster management.
To deal with these natural calamities occurring year after year, the Modi government should immediately provide additional disaster management funds to the states without any discrimination, the Congress chief asserted.

title: Congressman Eric Sorensen visits Fulton County to survey damage from July storms
message:
FULTON COUNTY, Ill. (WMBD) — Congressmen Eric Sorensen (D-17) visited Fulton County Thursday evening to assess damage from the severe storms that swept through the area in mid-July.
Fulton County leaders, and Illinois Emergency Management Agency representatives sat down with the congressman to explain the damage and what problems they are facing.
Leaders said in order to get help from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, the area needs to meet certain benchmarks.
There needs to be $23.6 in uninsured damages, which Fulton County is having trouble meeting.
We’re never going to reach that benchmark.”Sorensen plans to take what he learned from the Fulton County leaders to Washington D.C. and work to change the process to receive federal help to assess storm damage.
event_breakdown:
1) On August 13, 2022, Fulton County leaders met with Congressman Eric Sorensen to assess the damage caused by severe storms that struck the area in July. Fulton County is seeking assistance from the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), but needs to meet certain benchmarks to receive funding.
2) On August 18, 2022, a 6.0-magnitude earthquake struck Tibet, China, causing significant damage. There are no reports of injuries or fatalities, but the earthquake has caused landslides and damaged infrastructure.
3) On August 21, 2022, Tropical Storm Fred made landfall in Florida, bringing heavy rain and winds of up to 60 mph. The National Weather Service has issued a flash flood warning for parts of the state, and more than 1,000 people have been evacuated.

title: Noto getting  nowhere near enough support , says volunteer
message:
Tadakazu Sado, a 72-year-old from the city of Hiroshima, has dedicated himself to volunteering in the wake of numerous natural disasters since the 2011 Great East Japan Earthquake.
In June, Sado moved to the city of Wajima in Ishikawa Prefecture, a region badly hit by the Noto Peninsula earthquake in January.
Seven months after the disaster, he is increasingly concerned about waning interest in volunteering and declining support.
Following the New Year's Day earthquake, Sado immediately drove to the Noto region.
Initially, he planned to volunteer until his savings were depleted, as he had done with previous disasters.

title: Forecasters Warn Invest97 Could Develop into Tropical Storm
message:
(Miami, FL) -- The National Hurricane Center is keeping an eye on a storm system in the Atlantic that could develop into Tropical Storm Debby.
Forecasters say the system is currently producing thunderstorms over Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, and could threaten the U.S. mainland as early as this weekend.
Accuweather says the storm is headed for the eastern Gulf Coast, and is warning coastal residents from Florida to Louisiana to be ready.
Tropical storm watches or warnings could be required for portions of Florida later today.
The wave is expected to move near or over Cuba throughout the day and then emerge over the Straits of Florida tonight or Saturday.
event_breakdown:
Debby is expected to become the second named storm of the 2023 Atlantic hurricane season, according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC).
AccuWeather expects this storm to form in southwestern Gulf of Mexico in the next day or two but says it will be out over open ocean and pose no threat to land."
A storm system in the eastern Caribbean Sea could develop into a tropical depression or storm, creating dangerous rip currents and swells in areas of Mexico, the Cayman Islands, and Cuba beginning on Friday.
The system is expected to produce up to 2 feet of rain over Puerto Rico and parts of Hispaniola through Thursday, before pivoting northeast and moving near or over Cuba on Friday. As the storm moves back over water in the northwestern Caribbean or southeastern Gulf of Mexico this weekend or early next week, it could become the season's second named storm, according to AccuWeather meteorologists.
The wave is moving westward near 15 mph. A westward to west-northwestward motion is expected to continue during the next day or two, followed by a west-southwestward motion when it reaches the southwestern Gulf of Mexico on Friday. On the forecast track, the system is expected to be near the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico Friday night.
Locally heavy rainfall and flooding on Hispaniola and portions of Puerto Rico, including Haiti, could occur through Sunday. Across Jamaica, rainfall of 2 to 4 inches, with isolated maximum amounts of 8 inches, could result in areas of flash flooding during the next few days, according to the NHC.

message:

title: South Florida Prepares for Flooding from Potential Tropical Storm Debby
message:
South Florida officials are preparing for a system expected to develop into Tropical Storm Debby to dump heavy rain and cause flash flooding as early as tonight.
Lisa Spadafina heads the Miami-Dade Division of Environmental Resources Management (DERM) says, "The pumps are functional, storm drains are clear, and the canal system waters are lowered."
Still Miami Dade and Broward officials are warning residents to prepare for 1-5 inches of rainfall by managing their property and hardening their homes.
Mayor Trantalis says it is difficult to predict where the flooding will occur, but this system may slow down or stall which could lead to flash flooding.
In any case, he says the city has contracted with pump providers and lowered the water level in canals in preparation for whatever Mother Nature brings.

Florida is preparing for the arrival of Tropical Storm Debby, which is forecasted to bring torrential rain and gusty winds this weekend.
The National Hurricane Center (NHC) has issued tropical storm warnings and watches for parts of the state, from East Cape Sable to Bonita Beach, and parts of the Florida Keys.
The warning indicates that tropical storm conditions are expected within 36 hours, while the watch means these conditions are possible within 48 hours.
The system, currently designated as Potential Tropical Cyclone Four, is expected to develop into Tropical Depression Four by Saturday morning and then into Tropical Storm Debby before making landfall in Florida on Sunday or Sunday night.
The storm is then forecasted to track near the Southeast coast early next week, where it could intensify again if it remains over water.
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Debby: As of 8 a.m. Friday (July 28) Tropical Storm Debby has formed about 230 miles south of the mouth of the Mississippi River. The storm is expected to move toward the north-northwest at 5 to 10 mph during the next couple of days. Maximum sustained winds are 40 mph with higher gusts. Strengthening is forecast, and Debby could become a hurricane by Sunday. Tropical storm-force winds extend outward up to 70 miles mainly to the east of the center, NHC notes. A portion of the northern Gulf of Mexico could see winds of tropical storm force, The Weather Channel says.

title: Tropical system could bring heavy rain to the Charleston area
message:
CHARLESTON, S.C. (WCBD) – A tropical wave moving across Cuba is forecast to develop as it enters the Gulf of Mexico and nears the Florida west coast over the weekend.
Computer models show the system moving across Florida and out into the Atlantic just off the Georgia and South Carolina coasts by late Monday afternoon.
“Thankfully, most of it – the heaviest rain – will be out over the Gulf Stream and up into eastern North Carolina.
Down into the Lowcountry, we’re going to have moderate to heavy rain but not the worst of it,” said Storm Team 2 Meteorologist Josh Marthers.
Farther west means more rain and impacts, farther east means less rain and impacts,” Marthers said.

title: Cape Coral handyman gets months in jail after changing plea in Hurricane Ian fraud case
message:
Cape Coral handyman gets months in jail after changing plea in Hurricane Ian fraud caseThe city of Cape Coral showed major signs of damage after strong winds and flood waters as a result of Hurricane Ian impacted areas of the city on Thursday September 29, 2022.
This week, Aug. 1, 2024, a handyman who attempted to commit fraud in collecting money from residents to repair homes was sentenced to 9 months in jail.
A Cape Coral handyman accused of failing to complete work he was paid for after Hurricane Ian learned his fate this week after he changed his plea last month.
Hurricane Ian struck Southwest Florida as a Category 5 storm on Sept. 28, 2022, particularly devastating Cape Coral, Fort Myers Beach and Sanibel and Pine islands.
This article originally appeared on Naples Daily News: Cape Coral handyman sentenced to jail for Hurricane Ian fraud
event_breakdown: Cape Coral handyman sentenced to jail for Hurricane Ian fraud

title: First Alert Forecast : Toasty end to the week ; remaining hot after
message:
WILMINGTON, N.C. (WECT) - Your First Alert Forecast closes this Friday with a few roaming clouds and isolated storms, while lows will cool into the 70s.
Chances for rain & storms will trend higher early in the new week.
For now, your First Alert Weather Team is watching for potential impacts in the Cape Fear.
Stay plugged into your First Alert Forecast over the weekend as the forecast becomes more clear.
View your seven-day forecast: http://webpubcontent.gray.tv/wect/MAXSevendayWECT.jpgOr, extend your outlook with a ten-day forecast on your WECT Weather App.
event_breakdown:
WILMINGTON, N.C. (WECT) - The Cape Fear region is tracking an evolving wave of low pressure plus tropical moisture, which has the possibility to spawn a named "tropical" system soon. While some forecast guidance suggests a slight chance that this system could "recurve" to the northeast and stay well east of the Carolina coast, the more reliable guidance, suggests a west-northwestward track in the morning hours of Tuesday.
This low will have plenty of energy to exacerbate the pattern ahead, with rainy and stormy conditions expected during peak heating of the day. This could lead to a cluster of strong to severe storms eventually...especially near and south of the Cape Fear River.
News Channel 6 is tracking a disturbance with a northward track for Monday night through early Tuesday. This possible tropical system could spawn a system in the warm water with a channel of moisture. The cone of uncertainty suggests that this system could be anywhere along the North Carolina coast. The cone will morph as information continues to come in.

title: Tropical storm watches and warnings issued Friday , what about the Treasure Coast ?
message:
Heavy rainfall starting Saturday is the most likely impact to the Treasure Coast from a weather disturbance that triggered tropical storm watches and warnings Friday for portions of Florida’s West Coast, according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami.
If sustained winds reach 39 mph, it would become Tropical Storm Debby, the fourth named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season.
“We're forecasting it to become a tropical storm in 36 hours … sometime during the afternoon or evening on Saturday,” he said.

title: Potential cyclone 4 headed toward SW FL . Will be here Saturday
message:
A tropical storm warning has been issued for Southwest Florida, and heavy rains will drop six to eight inches of rain between Saturday and Wednesday.
A tropical storm warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area within 36 hours.
A watch means that tropical storm conditions are possible within the watch area, generally within 48 hours.
Potential cyclone heading to Southwest FloridaBefore it's called a depression, it's referred to as a potential cyclone, as it was during the 11 a.m. Friday update.
And Sunday it will be parallel to the coast between Fort Myers and Tampa.
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Alex is currently in the Gulf of Mexico and is forecast to make landfall along the Southwest Florida coast on Sunday. Flash flooding and damaging winds are expected throughout the region.

title: Track shows tropical disturbance could impact Central Florida this weekend
message:
2:45 p.m. updateGovernments in Central Florida are helping residents prepare for impacts from Potential Tropical Cyclone 4.
The National Hurricane Center is now tracking the tropical disturbance as “Potential Tropical Cyclone Four.”Photos: Track shows tropical disturbance could impact Central Florida this weekendPTC4 is not organized yet but has a more defined tracking path.
Central Florida will likely see tropical storm conditions throughout Sunday as the storm moves through the eastern Gulf of Mexico.
Read: See where you can get sandbags in Central FloridaEither way, Central Florida will likely see tropical storm conditions.
We will have some rain bands working in Sunday morning, with heavier rain bands Sunday afternoon and Sunday night.
event_breakdown: Potential Tropical Cyclone 4 may impact Central Florida this weekend. Residents are preparing for tropical storm conditions.

title: Heavy rain , flooding in SC Midlands likely as tropical system develops . Here when and how bad
message:
Tropical system to likely bring harsh weather to SC Midlands, NWS says.
When, what to expectChances of heavy rain and flooding across the Midlands into next week are growing with the rising threat of a tropical system in the Gulf, weather experts warn.
According to the National Weather Service in Columbia, there is 90% confidence that some sort of tropical system will form in the eastern Gulf of Mexico by early Sunday.
The interaction of the potential tropical system and a stalled storm front will yield high rain chances on Sunday, with flooding concerns from I-20 eastward.
An image that illustrates the development of a possible tropical system in the Gulf of Mexico.
event_breakdown:
Tropical system to likely bring harsh weather to South Carolina Midlands, NWS says

* Tropical threat forming in the eastern Gulf of Mexico likely to impact South Carolina Midlands with 90% confidence.
* Moderate to heavy rainfall on Sunday may increase flood concerns along I-20 eastwards.
* Forecasters had anticipated potential for development of a tropical system in the east-central Gulf of Mexico by Sunday.
* Interaction between potential tropical system and a stalled storm front likely to buildup rain chances Sunday.
* National Weather Service is anticipating heavy rain and flooding across the Midlands into next week.

title: Florida Gov . Ron DeSantis declares State of Emergency ahead of Gulf tropical system Invest 97L potential landfall
message:
TALLAHASSEE, Fla. (WCTV) - Florida Gov.
Ron DeSantis officially declared a State of Emergency Thursday afternoon as forecasters track a tropical disturbance heading toward Florida.
“The incoming heavy rainfall, flooding, and gusty winds will cause widespread power outages due to downed trees and powerlines,” he wrote.
The executive order applies to all counties in North Florida and many western counties in Central and South Florida.
See the complete list of counties in the full executive order below:This is a developing story.
event_breakdown:
Tropical disturbance heading toward Florida 
Ron DeSantis officially declares a State of Emergency for counties in North Florida and many western counties in Central and South Florida.

message:
